1.text:
The Three Strangers
by Thomas Hardy

5.text:
Among the few features of agricultural England
which retain an appearance

9.text:
but little modified by the lapse of centuries,
may be reckoned the high,

13.text:
grassy and furzy downs, coombs, or ewe-leases,
as they are indifferently

18.text:
called, that fill a large area of certain
counties in the south and south-

23.text:
If any mark of human occupation is met with
hereon, it usually

27.text:
takes the form of the solitary cottage of
some shepherd.

31.text:
Fifty years ago such a lonely cottage stood
on such a down, and may

38.text:
In spite of its loneliness, however, the

42.text:
than five miles from a county-
town.

46.text:
Five miles of irregular upland,
during the long inimical seasons, with their

51.text:

55.text:

59.text:

64.text:

72.text:

78.text:
But, in the present case, such a
kind of shelter had been disregarded.

83.text:
Higher Crowstairs, as the house
was called, stood quite detached and undefended.

88.text:
The only reason for its
precise situation seemed to be the crossing

92.text:
of two footpaths at right
angles hard by, which may have crossed there

97.text:
and thus for a good five
hundred years.

100.text:
Hence the house was exposed to the elements
on all sides.

103.text:
But, though the wind up here blew unmistakably
when it did blow, and the

107.text:
rain hit hard whenever it fell, the various
weathers of the winter season

111.text:
were not quite so formidable on the coomb
as they were imagined to be by

117.text:
The raw rimes were not so pernicious as in
the

120.text: hollows, and the frosts were scarcely so severe.

123.text:
When the shepherd and
his family who tenanted the house were pitied

126.text:
for their sufferings from
the exposure, they said that upon the whole

130.text:
they were less inconvenienced
by 'wuzzes and flames' (the hoarses and phlegms)

135.text:
than when they had lived by
the stream of a snug neighbouring valley.

140.text:
The night of March 28, 182-, was precisely
one of the nights that were

145.text: wont to call forth these expressions of commiseration.

149.text:
The level
rainstorm smote walls, slopes, and hedges

152.text:
like the clothyard shafts of

156.text:
Such sheep and outdoor animals as had no shelter
stood

159.text:
with their buttocks to the winds; while the

162.text:
to roost on some scraggy thorn were blown

168.text:
The
gable-end of the cottage was stained with

170.text:
wet, and the eavesdroppings

173.text:
Yet never was commiseration for the shepherd
more misplaced.

177.text:
For that cheerful rustic was entertaining
a large party

180.text:
in glorification of the christening of his
second girl.

184.text:
The guests had arrived before the rain began

188.text:
now assembled in the chief or living room

191.text:
A glance into

198.text:
and comfortable a nook as

candlesticks that were never used but at high-days,

of thorns, that crackled 'like the laughter

2593.text:
not knowing what I did, I turned and hurried
away.'

2597.text:
The narrator's manner and tone had the stamp
of truth, and his story made

2600.text: a great impression on all around.

2602.text:
'And do you know where your brother is
at the present time?' asked the magistrate.

2608.text:
I have never seen him since I closed this
door.'

2610.text:
'I can testify to that, for we've been between
ye ever since,' said the

2616.text:
'Where does he think to fly to?—what is
his occupation?'

2621.text:
''A said 'a was a wheelwright—a wicked rogue,'
said the constable.

2625.text:
'The wheels of clocks and watches he meant,
no doubt,' said Shepherd

2631.text: 'I thought his hands were palish for's trade.'

2633.text:
'Well, it appears to me that nothing can be
gained by retaining this poor

2637.text:
man in custody,' said the magistrate; 'your
business lies with the other,

2642.text:
And so the little man was released off-hand;
but he looked nothing the

2646.text:
less sad on that account, it being beyond
the power of magistrate or

2649.text:
constable to raze out the written troubles
in his brain, for they

2653.text:
concerned another whom he regarded with more
solicitude than himself.

2656.text:
When this was done, and the man had gone his
way, the night was found to

2661.text:
be so far advanced that it was deemed useless
to renew the search before

2667.text:
Next day, accordingly, the quest for the clever
sheep-stealer became

2670.text: general and keen, to all appearance at least.

2674.text:
But the intended
punishment was cruelly disproportioned to

2677.text:
the transgression, and the
sympathy of a great many country-folk in that

2681.text:
district was strongly on
the side of the fugitive.

2684.text:
Moreover, his marvellous coolness and daring
in hob-and-nobbing with the hangman, under

2689.text:
the unprecedented
circumstances of the shepherd's party, won

2694.text:
So that it
may be questioned if all those who ostensibly

2697.text:
made themselves so busy in
exploring woods and fields and lanes were

2701.text:
quite so thorough when it came
to the private examination of their own lofts

2707.text:
Stories
were afloat of a mysterious figure being occasionally

2709.text:
seen in some old
overgrown trackway or other, remote from turnpike

2713.text:
roads; but when a
search was instituted in any of these suspected

2720.text: Thus the days and weeks passed without tidings.

2724.text:
In brief; the bass-voiced man of the chimney-corner
was never recaptured.

2728.text:
Some said that he went across the sea, others
that he did not, but buried

2733.text: himself in the depths of a populous city.

2735.text:
At any rate, the gentleman in
cinder-gray never did his morning's work at

2739.text:
Casterbridge, nor met
anywhere at all, for business purposes, the

2743.text:
genial comrade with whom he
had passed an hour of relaxation in the lonely

2750.text:
The grass has long been green on the graves
of Shepherd Fennel and his

2753.text:
frugal wife; the guests who made up the christening
party have mainly

2757.text:
followed their entertainers to the tomb; the
baby in whose honour they

2762.text:
all had met is a matron in the sere and yellow
leaf.

2765.text:
But the arrival of
the three strangers at the shepherd's that

2768.text:
night, and the details
connected therewith, is a story as well known

2772.text:
as ever in the country
about Higher Crowstairs.

2778.text:
That is the end of
The Three Strangers
